This forecast is pretty late in the game but I'm hinging this on one key note; the question asked seems intentionally vague on what said referendum must be about ("a referendum vote on its relationship with the EU"). This makes no statement about a UK referendum to instead stay, nor should assumption be made as such. Thus I leave open one possible, albeit unlikely, sequence of events which prevents a certain "No". Note 1: The UK parliament will hold a vote on Tuesday on a potential deal, this could easily go either way. For lack of better information I'll default here to betting markets and give this odds of 40%
Note 2: In the event that a vote on the deal falls through there will be a vote for on a no-deal/deal Brexit, and subsequently on whether to delay the article 50 deadline. In normal circumstances I would hold these as essentially mutually inclusive (95%) to a no-vote on the existing deal, however certainty in UK politics seems to be a past-time given recent political divisiveness. So my best assertion is 80% on a vote to delay.
Note 3: In either a no-deal or delayed article 50 request circumstance the situation of a hard-border to Northern Ireland is still a looming cloud. Hedging a bet here to allow NI to remain (whether permanent or temporarily) would be wise, albeit unlikely. Accomplishing this through a snap-referendum (i.e. Greece in 2015) is an outcome with a non-zero possibility. My best guess in this event would be ~25% chance of this decision being made in the event that the above was also true (I know, a bit of a stretch).
Thus a resultant probability of (40%*80%*25%) = 8% chance of a referendum vote of this nature.

The UK parliament is entering a bizarre state. Mrs May only has a majority if the DUP votes with it. The DUP says it will stop supporting the government if parliament votes for the EU Withdrawal Agreement. In normal circumstances a government without a majority would lose a Vote of No Confidence which would lead (after another vote was lost) to a General Election, but things are not normal and what is likely to happen (if the EU WA goes through) is that the DUP and the former Conservative MPs (who resigned last week) and the former Labour MPs (who resigned last week) would vote to show they had confidence in Mrs May (who they clearly have no confidence in at all) because they don't want a general election. As both Labour and Conservatives have MPs openly defying their leaders both parties are in a bind. A general election would not change who the party leaders were, so how would MPs campaign? "vote for me and risk getting my party leader that I think is/would be a bad PM"? "vote for my party, when my party's policy on Brexit is either nebulous or to kick the can down the road and hope something turns up"? Would the ERG (hard Brexiteers) vote for No Confidence in May with the Labour Party, but the rebel MPs who have resigned from their parties for Mrs May to stay PM? So unless MPs are even more stupid than the public think they are they will not vote for a general election. I think the only way out of the mess is to extend A50 for at least 9 months, for parliament to agree the EU WA  (note passing the EU WA does not force the UK to leave EU until its ready) so that talks on the Future Agreement can start with the aim of having a detailed Future Agreement mapped out before the UK's EU Leaving Date is reached. Assuming a Future Agreement deal can be reached that would have to contain a solution to the Irish Border (so no backstop would be needed), At the point when a concrete deliverable FA that the EU agrees to exists either the UK Parliament would need to either approve it, or a general election would need to be help to give assumed approval or rejection, or a referendum would be needed so the public could ratify or reject the FA. If the parliament (or the public) reject the FA they can then Revoke A50. If A50 is not Revoked the UK laves the EU and starts the transition period (which would presumably be needed).  Anyone hoping that Brexit will be cleared up soon will be disappointed. My guess is that it will go on for at least two years and possibly four or five years.

REFERENDUM - 22 WEEKS NEEDED
At least 22 weeks would be needed to organise a referendum. A UCL article [1] found by @borisp on the mechanics of a second referendum says "the minimum time for these combined processes would be around 22 weeks, with additional time required if the referendum question were to follow a multi-option format." So we are already well beyond the time whereby a second referendum could happen before the close of this question. ELECTION - 6 TO 8 WEEKS NEEDED
Between 6 and 8 weeks would be needed for an election. The Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011 [2] subsequently amended by the Electoral Registration and Administration Act 2013 [3] specifies that parliament must be dissolved at the start of the 25th working day before general election day. A few more days would be needed for other technicalities, so about 6 weeks in total. Furthermore if an election is forced by the opposition tabling a motion of no confidence rather than the government calling for an election, then two more weeks could be needed because parliament must pass a motion of no confidence in the government, then within 14 days fail to pass a subsequent motion of confidence. That is also set out in the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011. [1] https://www.ucl.ac.uk/constitution-unit/publications/tabs/unit-publications/The_Mechanics_of_a_Further_Referendum_on_Brexit
[2] http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2011/14/pdfs/ukpga_20110014_en.pdf
[3] http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2013/6/pdfs/ukpga_20130006_en.pdf

Timeline on this makes either "Yes" resolution very untenable with the 29 March deadline. If TM loses the vote of no confidence today, the government has 14 calendar days to form again (30 January). If no new government is formed, parliament is dissolved and they must wait at least 25 business days (6 March) until the vote can be held. Parliament would then have to form a new government, elect a new PM, and either renegotiate with the EU AND vote on the renegotiated deal all before 29 March, or push the leave date since it is virtually impossible to hold another referendum before 29 March. - https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46890481 The dumpster fire that is Brexit would be come a full-on landfill wildfire if parliament chooses this option.

Both major parties (Conservative and Labour) seem opposed to a second referendum for now. Even if they came to decide for a new referendum, it will take time to decide on the question it asks, there must be an allowed period of several weeks for campaigning, etc. Since a second referendum may materially alter Brexit, I feel the UK could get an extension on the 29/03 deadline for that. Plus, they have the option of unilaterally withdrawing A50, so that gives them some leverage in asking for an extension. So I all but discard second ref before 29/03: 1%. For the snap election, that also takes time to organize. In 2017, when there was already a big hurry to do it, it took 51 days between it being announced and it happening. Apparently Labour is calling for snap elections if Parliament reject's May's current deal, which seems almost certain to happen. But there needs to be a 2/3 majority for snap elections to be called, or 434 votes. Even if every MP from every party but ruling coalition (Con+DUP) votes for it, you still need 111 votes from Con+DUP to pass it [1]. Given how the election went for Conservatives last time, I don't think they're eager for another one. And since there was already an election less than a year ago, it seems easier for anti-election MPs to explain away their votes against a snap election. In any case, there seems to be low support for a new election [2] --- out of 6 options, 16% said general elections are what should happen next. Still, if, as many predict, May's deal fails tomorrow in Parliament, and Labour proposes a no-confidence vote immediately, and it passes, then there is time for the elections to be held before deadline. That's quite a lot that needs to happen, but then again I've found Brexit to be very unpredictable, so I'll leave it at 33% for now --- but anticipate extremizing quickly over the next couple of weeks. Its tempting to put a figure on the chances of snap general election. It would be technically impossible to have a referendum according to the UK rules by March 29th. 
If the parliamentary vote on the Withdrawal Bill takes place on schedule January 15th the PM will (now, following today's amendment that was passed) have until Jan 21st to come up with a Plan B. If May does not have a Plan B and/or decides to resign the Conservative Party would presumably want to select as new leader. This would probably take a couple of weeks so lets say until Feb 5th, to have a general election would require a vote in parliament which presumably could take place while a new leader is selected, but realistically a general election probably could not take place until the beginning of March. At the same time that the Conservatives are selecting a new leader some new policies would be needed to deal with Brexit which would be in limbo, but parliament would need to do something to suspend A50 because a new government taking over in March would have no time to agree any new deal with the EU. 
So having an election when one party is in the middle of an already chaotic situation would not really be in anyone's interest. It might seem that Labour might want to benefit from the Conservatives  being in chaos, but to have an election would require some Conservatives to vote for it. However much some Conservatives disagree with Mrs May, voting with the opposition for an election before they have elected their new leader, which they need to do before agreeing a new policy seems very unlikely.
So I see a more likely sequence (a) May's Deal voted down (b) by early February parliament (cross party agreement) to postpone the A50 leaving date. But to get the EU to agree the UK parliament would need to agree with the EU some substantive action on Brexit e.g. a referendum or a general election. I think to get a majority in parliament for this its more likely that it would need to be agreed that the Conservatives could take several weeks to change their leader and their Brexit policy before a general election took place. So an April election seems more likely to me,

My thinking on this is influenced that both sides in reality want no deal, so if May's deal fails she will either resign or face a vote of no confidence in the house which she will lose on, given the catastrophe that no deal will seen to be by the majority of MP's. In that case, there would either be a leadership election in the Conservative party with a new leader who will want to renegotiate, so A50 will be extended, or a general election in which ever side wins will again want to renegotiate May's deal, in which case it again A50 would be extended. A soft renegotiation is better for the EU than no deal, and the EU excels at fudging things, nothing is set in stone as we have seen many times, and recently for example Frances breaching of the budget deficit rules. The electoral commission has a statutory duty to take at least 12 weeks to examine what is a 'fair question' and that is presumably after the Government has decided what it wants to ask, which would be a massive fight in itself (remain, no deal, 'leave', Mays deal, EEA, ect - which question?) which given we are 85 days away from leaving, leaves me thinking this is very unlikely to happen (yes, Parliament could legislate around this, but that is another massive argument). There is a six week window for a general election, which could conceivable be fought between a pro brexit tory and labour parties vs remain lib dems/new party, so I will leave that as more likely for now. The Tories have a huge incentive to avoid an election until Brexit is in the back window; Remainer discontent was a huge boost to Corbyn in the 2017 election, and could well win him another. The Tories's best bet is to get through Brexit, for May to resign, and then for a new PM to go to the country in search of another mandate for more normal domestic matters.  Likewise, the Tories also have a big incentive to avoid a second referendum, and I actually don't think Labour really benefit from one either, since it would take away their ability to play the "strategic ambiguity" card. There are legitimate concerns also that it would turn very ugly and corrode popular trust in the democratic process. A referendum would also have to be a far complicated affair than 2016, since simply re-running that vote achieves nothing if Leave won again - the UK would be stuck, as before. There would have to be multiple options on the table and a second preference voting system. Therefore, I'd say far the most plausible outcomes are a) that May's deal, perhaps in slightly amended form, surprises everyone by getting through the Commons due to Labour abstentions (not something Corbyn would be privately displeased about, for all that he'd have to be publicly enraged) or b) May's resignation, followed by an extension of the Article 50 period, something I imagine the EU would consent to fairly happily, given that the alternative is no-deal chaos, which benefits absolutely no one. The EU, in general, is a masterful organization at doing exactly one thing: kicking the can down the road. Sometimes this is disastrous, but more often than you'd think, can-kicking can be just what the doctor ordered...

A ‘No confidence’ vote A 'no confidence vote' takes place if the Prime Minister is no longer deemed fit to hold her role by her own MPs.  A total of 48 Tory MPs must write to the party's 1922 Committee chair Graham Brady to request a vote of confidence. If the Prime Minister won the confidence vote, she would remain in office and be awarded immunity for a year.  If the Prime Minister loses a confidence vote, she is obliged to resign and would be barred from standing in the leadership election that follows. She would need at least 158 votes from her 315 MPs to win. If she loses, what is known as a two-week ‘cooling off’ period will commence.  During this time, Parliament is dissolved, although Mrs May would still remain in Downing Street.  If the Tories cannot choose a new leader and form a new Government with the support of a majority of MPs within 14 calendar days, an early General Election is triggered. A new government could also include a cross-party allegiance and could dramatically change the government as we understand it now. However, if an alternative government cannot be formed with a majority support, the prime minister would be forced to set a date for another general election - the second while Mrs May has been at Downing Street.
